profileText: (Cousin of Morgan Gardner Bulkeley), a Senator from New York; born in Washington, Mass., February 8, 1811; moved with his parents to Windsor County, Conn., in 1822; attended the public schools and Bacon Academy, Colchester, Conn.; moved to Hartford, Conn., in 1828 and engaged in mercantile pursuits; member, city council of Hartford 1832; moved to New York City in 1836 and engaged in the wholesale grocery business, banking and brokerage; alderman of New York City 1849; member, State senate 1850-1855; State commissioner of immigration 1855-1858; chairman of the Republican National Committee 1856-1864; Governor of New York 1859-1862; during the Civil War served as major general of Volunteers in the Union Army 1861-1863, serving as commander of the Department of New York; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1863, to March 3, 1869; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1868; chairman, Committee on the Library (Fortieth Congress); chairman of the Republican National Committee 1872-1876; unsuccessful candidate for Governor in 1876; declined the office of Secretary of the Treasury in the Cabinet of President Chester Arthur in 1881; died in New York City, February 14, 1883; interment in Cedar Hill Cemetery, Hartford, Conn.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Rawley, James A. Edwin D. Morgan, 1811-1883: Merchant in Politics. 1955. Reprint. New York: AMS Press, 1968.

researchRecord.name: 1830-1880. 19 letters. Chiefly concerning the impeachment of Andrew Johnson and the commercial prospects for American-Chinese trade. Finding aid. Also in Eugene Kozlay papers, 1860-1878.
1849-1954. 302 items. Chiefly concerning campaigns, elections, and state and national politics.
1861-1863. 1 box. Chiefly military papers. Additional miscellaneous items in Richard Delafield letterpress copybook, 1862-1864; and Briggs family papers, 1802-1868.

1859-1862. 16 volumes. Gubernatorial records including registers and index to incoming correspondence (1861-1862); telegrams received and sent (1861-1862); Bureau of Military Statistics administrative correspondence files (1859-1875); and inspector general's office copies of correspondence forwarded from the governor's office (1861-1862).

1830-1872. 50 cubic feet. Correspondence; letterpress copybooks; scrapbooks; and bookkeeping journals, ledgers, mortgage bonds, bills, and receipts relating to personal, business, and political affairs; and Civil War papers consisting of vouchers, contracts, minutes, and financial records. Finding aid. Additional items in various other collections including Charles Lanman collection, 1829-1869 (bulk 1855-1869).
325 letters (1850-1876) in various collections. Finding aid.
